items.title: San Francisco reopens some businesses and activities as it moves into the State's Red Tier
items.summary: Beginning Wednesday, March 3, San Francisco will open up activities such as indoor dining, indoor fitness, and indoor museums and aquariums in accordance with State and with additional local limits.

items.title: San Francisco moves to phase 1b of COVID-19 vaccinations, expands eligibility to educators, child care, emergency services, food and agriculture workers
items.summary: Vaccine supply remains limited, but more San Franciscans and workers are now eligible to make appointments for vaccination as they become available.

items.title: San Francisco lifts local 10-day quarantine order but urges against non-essential travel
items.summary: Those who travel out of state or more than 120 miles from home still advised to quarantine for 10 days.

items.title: Some COVID-19 vaccine sites paused due to lack of supply
items.summary: Both Moscone and City College sites will pause. No existing appointments will be cancelled. Moscone will pause for 1 week, and reopen once more vaccine supply is available. City College will resume on February 19 for second doses only.

items.title: San Francisco announces plan to expand vaccine eligibility to workers in education and childcare, emergency services, and food sectors
items.summary: Starting on Feb. 24, San Francisco will move to Phase 1B, Tier 1 of the state’s population prioritization plan and begin vaccinating people who work in education and childcare, emergency services, and food and agriculture sectors, while continuing to vaccinate healthcare workers.

items.title: High-volume COVID-19 vaccination site to open at Moscone Center on February 5
items.summary: Healthcare workers and community members age 65 and over can book appointments. Supply is limited, and you may not be able to book an appointment right now, even if you are eligible.
